question: Question_06_(c)
statement:
Explain how the orthogonality of the functions $e^{2\pi inx}$ allows you
to relate the inner product in
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_06_(b)}{part
(b)} to the sum

\[\sum_{n = -\infty}^\infty |c_n|^2\] Use your answer to to calculate
the infinite sum

\[\sum_{n = 1}^\infty n^{-2}\]
sols:
According to Parseval's identity it holds that

\[\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty |c_n|^2 = \int_0^1 |f(x)|^2 dx\]

where \emph{c\textsubscript{n}} are the Fourier coefficients of
\emph{$f$(x)}. In
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_06_(b)}{part
(b)} we calculated the right hand side and found that the above equals
to \emph{1/3}.

In
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_06_(a)}{part
(a)} we found that the Fourier coefficients are $c_{0} = \frac{1}{2}$
and $c_{n}=-\frac{1}{2\pi in}$. Hence

\begin{align*}
\frac13 &= \sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty |c_n|^2 \\
&= |c_0|^2 + 2\sum_{n=1}^\infty \left|c_n\right|^2 \\
&= \left|\frac12\right| + 2 \sum_{n=1}^\infty \left|-\frac1{2\pi in}\right|^2 \\
&= \frac14 + \frac1{2\pi^2} \sum_{n=1}^\infty \frac1{n^2}
\end{align*}

Solving for the remaining series yields the final answer

\[\sum_{n=1}^{\infty} n^{-2}=\frac{\pi^2}{6}\]
hints:
Use Parseval's identity

\[\sum_{n=-\infty}^\infty |c_n|^2 = \frac{1}{2\pi}\int_{-\pi}^\pi |f(x)|^2 \, dx,\]

and your results from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_06_(a)}{part
(a)} and
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH307/December_2010/Question_06_(b)}{part
(b)}.
